w:r.w:t: The Virtual Data Language (VDL) comes in two flavors, textual and XML. This document deals with the textual version of VDL, also known as

The language syntax is shown using railroad diagrams. In these diagrams, rectangular boxes show terminals of the language; that is, tokens that must appear exactly as shown in the box. Round elements show non-terminals of the language. Non-terminals are place-holders for another rule.
. These two elements may be repeated in any order any number of times. The term
applies when talking about either element.
A transformation starts with the keyword
followed by a fully qualified definition identifier (
). This identifier comes in various shapes, and is explained in the next section.
The transformation identifier is followed by an open parenthesis, a list of formal arguments (
-list), and a closing parenthesis. This list of formal arguments is optional. The parentheses are mandatory. These elements constitute the header of a transformation.
an opening curly brace, a list of optional transformation body elements, and a closing curly brace. The transformation body itself may be empty; however the curly braces are mandatory.
Transformations come in two flavors, simple or compound. The body elements determine the flavor of a transformation. If there is a
statement inside the body, the transformation becomes a compound transformation (
body element may appear in both flavors of transformations, the
element are mutually exclusive. The absence of both implies a simple transformation.
Note: Future versions may permit an empty transformation body by specifying a semicolon instead of an empty set of curly braces. The gray dashed line denotes this fact.
a name (sometimes called identifier) within this namespace, and
The namespace and version portions of the fully qualified definition identifier are optional. If a namespace is present, two colons
The two colons must be one token, no spaces between them.

separate the namespace from the name. If a version is present, a single colon separates it from the name. There mustn't be any white-spaces between the different parts of a fully qualified definition identifier nor around the colons.

It is highly recommended to use only characters in the namespace and name portion which are also permissible in the C programming language. We strongly suggest refraining from using characters not found in C identifiers. The following set of regular expressions shows the permissible characters in a TR or DV identifier:
characters in a TR or DV identifier:

Please also avoid periods, hyphens and slashes in identifiers. The period or the hyphen is a candidate in future releases to partition a namespace hierarchy. They would thus become a forbidden character. A hyphen in identifiers is problematic for the scanner, and is thus slated for removal in future releases.

must start with an alphabetical character, a slash, or an underscore. Alphanumerical characters, slashes, underscores, periods and hyphens may follow it. The inclusion of slashes and periods allows a user for self-imposed hierarchy creation in namespaces. There is no explicit support for namespace hierarchies yet.

Warning: Only such characters as are also permissible in C language identifiers should be used. The use of hyphens is strongly discouraged! Periods and slashes are discouraged unless used to denote a namespace hierarchy.
It is recommended to always use a namespace with any fully qualified definition identifier.

, must start with an alphabetical character. Alphanumerical characters, underscores or hyphens may follow it. The name is the minimal and mandatory member of any fully qualified definition identifier.
Warning: The use of periods, slashes and hyphens in the name is strongly discouraged!

must start with a numerical digit. Further digits or periods may follow it. Unfortunately, there are no user callbacks to compare versions correctly - versions are currently compared using string comparison. The version comparison becomes important when mapping a

It is recommended to use only non-negative integers for the version number. Future releases are slated to make the version a true natural number. There are a couple of useful practices for the version number:
Monotonously increasing integers from 0 or 1 upwards.
The formal argument list is optional. If formal arguments exist, each formal argument constitutes a
followed by the identifier of the formal argument
may be specified in a long or alternative short form. Permissible values for the type field are:
This type denotes a symbolic argument, either a string or a number that is to be passed verbatim. The omission of a type also denotes the symbolic argument.
type denotes filenames that are consumed, at least logically.
type denotes filenames that are produced.
type is reserved for compound transformations to denote temporary glue filenames. Glue Filenames are produced by a
in a compound transformation, and are consumed by another
The formal argument identifiers follow the syntax of the C programming language for identifiers. The scope of formal arguments pertains to the
itself. If the identifier is associated with a list value, it must be followed by the open bracket and close bracket tokens.
It is permissible to assign default values to any formal argument. Default arguments are not, unlike C++, limited to the final formal argument declarations. They may occur where needed.
The rules for default arguments are similar to
. If a simple scalar formal argument is of type none, the default argument must be a
element. If the scalar formal argument has any other type, the default argument must an

. Similar rules apply to list formal arguments. With list values, the list of default argument is enclosed in brackets. Each element within the list must be of the correct element. The list may be empty, denoted by a closing bracket immediately following an opening bracket.
Commas separate multiple formal arguments in the formal argument list. The following example just illustrates various ways to specify formal arguments, omitting the transformation body:
The previous examples all illustrate passing a
argument. The order of the arguments is at the time of this writing of no concern. In the first case, a caller must supply values for both arguments,
. If no default exists, a binding must always be provided by the
In the next case, a caller may omit the binding of text for
. In this case, the supplied default value is taken. If the caller
to overwrite the default value, the caller must supply a value (binding) for
The simple transformation consists of any number (including zero) of
statements. Each statement must be terminated by a semicolon Pascal style.
keyword; however, it is optional in almost all cases. Since the identifier serves currently no purposes, it should best be left out. The equals character is mandatory, followed by one or more
constant, or a reference to a formal argument identifier (
). These are defined in a later section.

keyword is followed by a the identifier for a profile's namespace. A period, or a double colon, separates the namespace of the profile from the key within the namespace. The mandatory equals character introduces one or more
constants and references to formal argument identifiers. These are defined in a later section.
TR t3( in f1, out f2 ) {
A compound transformation consists of at least one
statements. Each statement must be terminated by a semicolon Pascal style.
. In other words, it behaves like a
, it offers the soft binding to matching
reserved word. The list of call actual arguments (
) is optional. Commas separate multiple entries. The
) or references to the enclosing transformation's formal argument identifiers (

keyword is followed by a the identifier for a profile's namespace. A period, or a double colon, separates the namespace of the profile from the key within the namespace. The mandatory equals character introduces one or more
constants and references to formal argument identifiers. These are defined in a later section.
The actual argument binding inside a
statement only allows elements that are permissible inside a

. This process is called binding. The equal character is followed either by a list or a scalar. If the called formal argument is a scalar, only the lower path may be taken. If the formal argument in the called transformation is a list, either the elements are enumerated between brackets, or a bound variable reference from the encompassing transformation may be used to pass the list.
specifies the permissible arguments inside any
. Please note in the railroad diagrams which exhibit
element is a single element, a possible concatenation of
elements, or a comma-separated list of simple
element is a C-style string in quotes. A backslash can be used to quote both, the quote and the backslash.
The first example shows an empty string. The next example shows a string with some content. The 3
example shows how to escape quotes inside a string. The final example shows how to escape backslashes inside a string.
element is a reference to a formal argument. The typical old-style

element starts with the dollar sign. Its argument, the identifier of the formal argument, is set in curly braces. A simplified version uses just the bound variable identifier, as commonly used in procedural programming languages.

The simplified reference to formal argument identifiers (also known as bound variables) is shown in the top path. If the bound variable is used with the same input/output type as declared in the formal argument type, just the identifier needs to be specified. If type casting is required, C-style type casts can be used for simple casts. A C-style type cast puts the target type into
While list type variables may be used with the simple notation, any special rendering requires the old-style notation.

The optional rendering, marked green, changes the default appearance in the command-line arguments and profile components, when rendering a list value. If a rendering is present, the vertical bar character separates it from the other parts of the
element. A rendering consists either of one or three
If your rendering requires to specify just the separating string between list elements, the 1-string case applies. In this case, the string is the only rendering element.
If you also require to specify the introduction (prefix) string of a list, or the

end (suffix) of a list, you need to use the 3-string case. In the 3-string case, colons separate all strings. The contents of the first string is placed before the first list element, the separator string in the second string between all list elements, and the contents of the third string as suffix after the list.
is described in the formal argument list. If a
is used, it must be suffixed by a colon character. The type casts to either
is usually necessary, if the bound variable's type is
The final and mandatory part is the name of the formal argument identifier (
The first case shows the simplest reference to a bound variable by just using its name. The next line shows an equivalent form, using old-style dollar-brace notation. The 3
line shows a simple type-cast variable reference, with the 4

The first list case shows a rendering which will render each list item separated by just a hyphen, no spaces. The second list also casts the type of the list. The final list item will render the list by putting it between brackets, and separating each element with a comma. If the
contained three elements a, b, and c, the output would look like this:
followed by a fully qualified definition identifier (see above). The identifier uniquely describes the
The arrow operator, which consists of a hyphen immediately followed by a less-than character, separates the derivation identifier from the transformation mapping (
). The transformation mapping allows a flexible binding of the given
by their versioning. The in-depth support in the abstract planner is lacking, though.
Mandatory parenthesis enclose the actual argument list (
). The actual argument list is optional. It binds formal arguments to actual values. A
specification is terminated with a semicolon.
. It is very similar to a fully qualified definition identifier, but differs with the version specification. As with the fully qualified definition identifier, white-spaces anywhere within the
The namespace and name rules are the same as for
. The version left of the comma is a minimum inclusive version number. The syntax of this version is the same as the
version. The version to the right of the comma is a maximum inclusive version number. The syntax of this version is the same as the
The syntax diagram looks more complicated than the matter actually is. There are essentially four cases to distinguish:
If a colon does not follow the name, there is no version specification, and no version matching will be done. In this case, all versions match.
If the name is followed by a colon, one of the following mappings must be applied:
The regular case specifies two version number, a minimum inclusive version followed by a comma, followed by a maximum inclusive version. An example is "name:10,20".
The case with an open maximum version only specifies the minimum version followed by a comma, e.g. "name:10,".
The case with an open minimum version only specified a comma followed by the maximum permissible version, e.g. "name:,20".
The list of actual argument in a
binds values to formal arguments of a
The syntax is similar to the argument list for a
. The difference is in the permissible elements in the list. Being inside a
Each actual argument names the formal argument in the called transformation to bind to (

). Either a list or a scalar follows the mandatory equals character. If the bound formal argument is a scalar, only the lower path may be taken. If the formal argument in the called transformation is a list, the elements are enumerated between brackets,
specifies the permissible arguments inside a
are permitted. Please note in the railroad diagrams which exhibit
use, if it is a single
elements, or a comma-separated list of
element is a C-style string in quotes. A backslash can be used to quote both, the quote and the backslash. Please refer to section
element describes a logical filename. Any LFN is introduced by the "at" character, with further arguments in curly braces.
describes a logical file as either
. The latter is usually reserved for transient files. A colon separates the logical filename itself from the type. Please note the use of the
element for the filename - it must be enclosed in quotes.
In case of transient filenames, the pattern to construct temporary filenames can be specified as follows: A colon separates the pattern string, a

element again, from the filename. The pattern is optional. In the presence of the pattern, the filename is deemed transient. Transient files are neither transferred nor cataloged. It will not participate in the staging process, except for inter-pool transfers as necessary. In the absence of the pattern, the file is assumed to be a fully tracked, transferable and
file. However, this behavior can be modified as shown below.
The first file specification shows a typical input file. The 2
file specifies a transient file, which will neither be registered nor transferred to the final staging area. However, it may be transferred to different sites, if the consuming jobs require so.

Recent additions permit to specify a finer control over the handling of the file. The options are the last part of any logical filename syntax. A vertical bar separates the options from any preceding items like the filename or pattern. Zero or more one-character codes flag how a concrete planner is supposed to deal with the file.
don't fail, if not in RC
fail if not found in RC
The following equivalences apply to short-cuts and compatibility with previous versions of VDL:
